column1: High school students graduating on time
Minnesota, 2003-2016
Graduation rate (on time)
Number of graduates
Total potential graduates
Notes:
Data year represents the second year of a school year; e.g., 2016 data
represents the 2015-2016 school year.
Data in this measure reflect the four-year on-time graduation rate as
described in the National Center for Education Statistics
Exclusion-Adjusted Cohort Graduation Indicator and reiterated in the USDE
guidance No Child Left Behind â€“ High School Graduation Rate. This rate
considers first-time ninth grade students in the cohort, adds students
transferring into the cohort, subtracts students transferring out of the
cohort, and computes how many graduate â€œon timeâ€ù (within four years).
Further information about the USDE guidance may be found at
http://www.ed.gov/policy/elsec/guid/hsgrguidance.pdf
The Four-Year Graduation Rate published here is similar but not identical
to the National Governors Association (NGA) rate previously published on
Compass. The NGA rate permitted students receiving special education and
recent immigrant students with limited English proficiency to be assigned
to different cohorts to allow them more time to graduate, while the
Four-Year Graduation Rate does not allow for this. The NGA rate also
permitted students who graduate with modified high school diplomas to count
as graduates, while the Four-Year Graduation Rate excludes any alternative
degrees that are not fully aligned with a Stateâ€™s academic standards
(e.g., a General Education Development (GED) credential, a modified
diploma, or a certificate of attendance).
Minnesota previously made an adjustment to the calculation that removed
first-time ninth grade students (and other students that had joined the
cohort) if their enrollment period was very brief. This can occur when a
student is temporarily placed in an alternative program or other
specialized educational facility and the grade is reported differently than
in the regular school. During a final review, the U.S. Department of
Education indicated that this adjustment was inappropriate and should be
removed. Students who are served as first-time ninth grade students, even
for brief periods of time, are expected to join a cohort and graduate
within four years. Data in this measure for all available years reflect the
new standards that include these briefly-enrolled students in the cohort.
Sources:
Minnesota Department of Education. http://education.state.mn.us
Data downloaded from http://www.mncompass.org on 04/26/2018
